newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's financial sector readying for EU - experts.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's financial sector readying for EU - experts.

text.p: Hungary's financial sector is ripe for integration into the European Union, but it needs certain transitional rules before reaching the standards of developed countries, a group of government experts said on Wednesday.
Hungary has already joined the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), and hopes to become a member of the European Union (EU) by the year 2000.

"The financial sector is in a good starting position for integration into the EU, because the large western companies already appeared here years ago," Mihaly Patai, Chairman of the insurance company Hungaria Biztosito Rt said.

However, the quality of financial services will have to improve before Hungary will allow foreign financial institutions to open branches by the end of 1997, as it promised to the OECD, Eva Varhegyi, expert of the financial research company Penzugykutato Rt added.

The OECD should also allow Hungary to make it more difficult for foreign companies to establish branches, perhaps by setting high capitalisation requirements, or otherwise many Hungarian banks may not be able to withstand the competition, the experts said.
Hungary's deposit insurance will also need certain transitional regulations because meeting the EU's requirements would be too expensive for the banks, Varhegyi said.

If a bank goes bankrupt, deposit insurance should cover the repayment of at least 20,000 Ecu's for each depositor according to EU requirements, but Hungarian banks cannot afford to insure more than some 5,000 Ecus currently, she added.
